body_content.explanation: used to refer to a male object of a verb that is the same person or animal as the subject of the verb:
examples: Most nights he would cry himself to sleep.

body_content.explanation: used to emphasize a particular man, boy, or male animal:
examples: Did you want to talk to the chairman himself, or could his personal assistant help you?
Tom was going to buy a bookcase, but in the end he made one himself.

body_content.explanation: If a man or boy does something by himself, he does it alone or without help from anyone else:
examples: Little Timmy made that snowman all by himself.
Johnny's got the apartment to himself next week.

body_content.explanation: not to be, seem, or feel as happy or as healthy as usual:
examples: Is Tom all right? He doesn't seem quite himself this morning.

body_content.explanation: used when describing or asking about a man's state of mind when he is physically ill:
examples: He's well enough in himself - he just can't shake this cold off.

body_content.explanation: used to refer to an object of a verb that is the same person or animal as the subject of the verb, when referring to a person or animal whose gender is not known or not considered to be important:
examples: Any fool can teach himself to type.
When a student needs to leave the classroom, he must sign himself out.
